title: How do dogs "see" with their noses? - Alexandra Horowitz

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: It is only relevant to the dog's sense of hearing.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.text: They are only relevant in certain situations

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A number that is multiplied by the frequency to determine the change in energy

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They oscillate at a slightly different frequency than other types of atoms

options.label: D
options.text: They are the only type of atom that can be used in GPS satellites

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to calculate the speed of light

options.label: B
options.text: It is used to determine the distance to a satellite

options.label: C
options.text: It is used to correct for errors in the measurements

options.label: D
options.text: It is not used in determining your location

options.label: A
options.text: To emit radio signals that travel at the speed of sound

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: To filter out harmful light for the eye.

options.label: A
options.text: To detect light and convert it into signals for the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: To regenerate damaged cells in the retina.

options.label: C
options.text: To produce excess energy for the eye.

options.label: D
options.text: To filter out harmful light for the eye.

title: What is a gift economy? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a gift economy and a barter system?

options.text: A gift economy involves the exchange of goods and services for money, while a barter system involves the exchange of goods and services without money.

options.label: C
options.text: A gift economy involves the accumulation of material wealth, while a barter system involves the accumulation of social wealth.

options.label: D
options.text: A gift economy involves the exchange of goods and services between individuals, while a barter system involves the exchange of goods and services between businesses.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a potlatch feast?

options.label: B
options.text: To accumulate social wealth by giving away livestock and blankets.

options.label: C
options.text: To exchange goods and services for money.

multiple-choice.question: How does the status gained from gift ceremonies determine land ownership among the Toraja people of Indonesia?

options.label: A
options.text: The status gained from gift ceremonies determines who owns the land.

options.label: B
options.text: The status gained from gift ceremonies determines who has the right to use the land.

options.label: C
options.text: The status gained from gift ceremonies determines who has the right to sell the land.

options.label: D
options.text: The status gained from gift ceremonies has no effect on land ownership.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to keep the gift cycle going in a gift economy?

options.label: A
options.text: To repay a gift immediately, or with something of exactly equal value.

options.label: B
options.text: To keep someone always indebted to someone else.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a gift economy in a modern context?

options.label: A
options.text: A company that sells goods and services for money.

options.label: B
options.text: A community that operates as a mix of barter and a gift economy, where selling things for money is strictly taboo.

options.label: C
options.text: A system of intellectual property rights.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of a gift economy in a commercialized world?

options.label: B
options.text: To strengthen bonds through giving and reciprocity.

options.label: D
options.text: To exchange goods and services for money.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point of a gift economy?

options.label: A
options.text: That a gift is truly a gift if it comes with obligations or involves some social payoff.

options.label: B
options.text: That a gift is truly a gift if it does not come with obligations or involve some social payoff.

options.label: C
options.text: That a gift economy is exclusive to small-scale societies outside the industrialized world.

options.label: D
options.text: That a gift economy is a system where goods and services are exchanged for money.

title: How does cancer spread through the body? - Ivan Seah Yu Jun
